summary: the normality of all proteomics, western-blotting and qPCR data was evaluated with the Shapiro-Wilk test. the unpaired Student's t test or one-way ANOVA was selected when the distribution of the data was normal. HepG2.2.15 cells were grown in a humidified incubator at 37 °C with 5% CO2. the cells were plated at 5 106 cells in T-75 flasks and grown in complete DMEM for 24 h at 37 °C. RNA Isolation, Reverse Transcription, and qPCR for Gene Expression TRIzol Reagent (Thermo, MA) was used to extract total RNA as specified in the accompanying manual. Relative gene expression was measured with the ABI Prism 7500 sequence detection system (Applied Biosystems) plasmids containing only the HBV gene preS1 were extracted from E. coli transformants with the GeneJET Plasmid Miniprep Kit (Fermentas, MA) the concentration of extracted plasmids was adjusted and diluted in a range of 107, 106, 105, 104, 103, and 102 copy/l. the purple formazan crystals were dissolved with dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO, Riedel-deHan, NJ) and measured with ELISA plate reader (Thermo) at wavelength 570 nm. the absorbance values of cells treated with each concentration of drug were compared with that of control (untreated) cells and % cell viability was calculated. labeling efficiency was tested, and we found that greater than 99% of peptides were labeled. after combining these three samples, the mixed labeled-peptides were dried in a SpeedVac centrifuge at room temperature. the pooled peptides were separated into 10 fractions to reduce complexity using the Pierce High pH Reversed-Phase Peptide Fractionation Kit (thermo) precursor ions with unassigned charge states, a charge state of +1, or a charge state of greater than +8 were excluded. a dynamic exclusion of 30 s was used. the peaklist-generating software was Proteome DiscovererTM software 2.1. bioinformatics We compiled a list of defense response to virus using a variety of resources as three times with TBST and probed with anti-OAS3 (ab64163, abcam, MA), anti-SAMHD1 (#12361, CST, MA), anti-STAT1 (#9175, CST), or anti-GAPDH (#5174, CST, MA) antibodies. n = 3 was set for western-blotting and qPCR experiments. all proteins identified by mass spectrometry were input as background. resulting log values were conservatively adjusted by subtracting log value corresponding to total of possible study/study combinations in the database. one million HepG2.2.15 cells were seeded into 6-well plates with 1 ml media and maintained in complete DMEM for 24 h. these cells were left untreated or treated with 1, 10, 100 or 1000 ng/ml of IFN-3 (5259-IL-025, R&D Systems, MN) for proteomics analysis, these cells were plated at 5 106 cells in T-75 flasks and grown in complete extracted using the QIAamp DNA Blood Mini Kit. t values were used to calculate the amount of HBV DNA in the samples. a p value less than 0.05 was considered significant. at 37 °C and iodoacetamide RNA Isolation, Reverse Transcription, and qPCR for Gene Expression TRIzol Reagent (Thermo, MA) was used to extract total RNA. conditions for reverse transcription were as specified in the manual. preS1 plasmids were extracted from E. coli transformants with the GeneJET Plasmid Miniprep Kit (Fermentas, MA) the concentration of extracted plasmids was adjusted and diluted in a range of 107, 106, 105, 104, 103, and 102 copy/l. the fluorescent intensities were specified as Ct values. the absorbance values of cells treated with each concentration of drug were compared with that of control (untreated) cells and % cell viability was calculated. the experiment was performed in triplicate. labeling efficiency was tested, and we found that greater than 99% of peptides were labeled. after combining these three samples, the mixed labeled-peptides were dried in a SpeedVac centrifuge at room temperature. the pooled peptides were separated into 10 fractions to reduce complexity using the Pierce High pH Reversed-Phase Peptide Fractionation Kit. the peaklist-generating software used in this study was Proteome DiscovererTM Software 2.1 (Thermo). the SEQUEST-HT search engine was employed in data processing. well. the amount of tryptic peptide of each sample was determined with the Pierce Quantitative Fluorometric Peptide Assay (Thermo) the mixtures were incubated with 0.5% trifluoroacetic acid (TFA) for CALR, a player in this process, was down-regulated. qPCR work confirmed significant up-regulation of these IFNs. it is likely that the increase in IFN expression because of RIG-I up-regulation could lead to more production of IFNs at the protein level and in turn activate IFN receptors as positive feedback. cyclophilin D (PPIF) was the most up-regulated protein in our study on IFN-3 treatment. RNA-binding proteins, particularly spliceosome components, were both up- and down-regulated on IFN-3 treatment versus control. a simple comparison between IFN-3 versus IFN-2a could lead to errors in interpretation. for example, the observation that IFN-3 results in up-regulation or down-regulation of a protein versus IFN-2a renders an uninteresting result if IFN-3 does not have any significant effect. this scenario can be seen in outcomes #3 and #25 in Fig. 12. we did not identify proteins clearly related to antiviral processes in these two outcome groups. this reason pointed to broader unbiased analysis. the resulting enrichment groups were subjected to 2-D cluster analysis. the results could help point toward differential effects of IFN-3 versus IFN-2a. the results could help point Upon IFN-3 treatment, we found several biological processes expected to be canonically regulated on general IFN stimulation. however, several biological processes not previously emphasized upon interferon stimulation emerged from this work. proteins in red and green text represent up- and down-regulated proteins. proteins in red and green text represent up- and down-regulated proteins. antiviral proteins (EIF2AK2, IFIT1, and IFIT2) involved in protein synthesis increased in treated cells. almost all identified translation initiation factors (EIF1AY, EIF2S3, EIF2B1, EIF3B, EIF4G1, EIF4B, EIF4G2, and EIF5A) decreased. all deubiquitinating enzymes (DUBs) identified in this study decreased because of IFN-3 treatment. upstream of these processes, core proteasome components, PSMA7, PSMB7, and PSMG2 were up-regulated with no exception. several effector molecules involved in peptide loading on class I HLA were up-regulated. the italic red text represents proteins with increased expression levels that failed to reach statistical significance. qPCR work confirmed significant up-regulation of these IFNs. IFN-3 up-regulated the expression of RIG-I and IFIT3. IFN-3 also elevated the expression of OASL and TRIM25. these proteins promote type I and type III IFN production. the same pattern applies to proteins shown to bind to the splicing factor U2AF2 (log p = 5 and 13, respectively) the same pattern applies to proteins shown to bind to the splicing factor U2AF2 (log p = 6 and 9, respectively) the same pattern applies to proteins shown to bind to the splicing factor U2AF2 (58). IFITM3 was significantly up-regulated upon treatment with both IFNs. but this effect was significantly stronger upon IFN-3 treatment. outcome #24 where IFN-3 caused down-regulation whereas IFN-2a did not produce significant effects. in most cases where proteins were up-regulated upon IFN-2a treatment, “interferon signaling” and/or “class I MHC mediated antigen processing & presentation” terms were apparent. specific terms related to “translation” and “metabolism of RNA” were significantly associated with 13 out of 17 different outcome groups. the number in parentheses refers to the number of identified proteins in the group. the proteins in each group that might be involved in suppressing HBV replication are shown in colored boxes specifying various processes, particularly antiviral. only two studies have focused on the effects of IFN- treatment of HBV-transfected cells. a comparison against a type I IFN showed that IFN- showed greater potency in viral elimination at the 6 h time point, but potency was equivalent at 24 h. the effects of IFN- treatment have not been studied with high-resolution mass spectrometry to date. the 3/c list significantly overlapped (p value = 1013) transcripts whose up/down-regulation patterns mirror those of RIG-I transcripts reported in the ARCHS4 resource. the /c list gave p value = 1018, perhaps illustrating the expected difference in potency. a small molecule-based inhibition of proteasome activity could restrain the anti-HBV activity of type I IFN in vitro. the immunoproteasome is distinct from the constitutive proteasome in the composition of its catalytic subunits. IFN treatment has not previously been shown to up-regulate RIG-I pathway components in HBV infected cells. we found that treating HepG2.2.15 with IFN-3 increased the expression of RIG-I. we observed elevated expression of RIG-G, known to enhance the activity of RIG-I. HBx protein interacts with 14-3-3 proteins resulting in enhancement of Raf-1 kinase activity together with control of hepatocyte growth (80). the down-regulation of cyclophilin D upon IFN-3 treatment suggests that this molecule may play a role in inhibition of HBV replication. ER calcium-binding chaperone involved in regulation of calcium homoeostasis. inhibition of IRF-7 translocation into the nucleus was induced by CALR. this group showed that CALR inhibited JAK-STAT pathway induction by IFN- by inhibiting STAT1 phosphorylation, diminishing expression of PKR and OAS. 9 knockout and treatment with a specific CDC42 inhibitor in HBx-Huh7 cells (92) reduced cell proliferation and promoted apoptosis in these cells. despite the division of treatment outcomes into 27 non-intersecting protein groups, unbiased Reactome enrichment analysis repeatedly elicit an RNA-metabolism/translation theme. 4.7, 3.2, 4.8, 8.2, and 5.3 are seen only once out of six outcomes where IFN-2a treatment results in significantly more abundant protein expression. this result could imply differential regulation of these ER targeting proteins versus IFN-2a treatment. IFITM3 strongly up-regulated in our own 3/2a comparison (outcome #1), was the single most significantly up-regulated transcript in the 3/2 comparison (p value = 1010) we should reiterate the points that our experimental design did not allow for discrimination of kinetic effects. we reported significant up-regulation of immunoproteasome components, restoration of HBV-inhibited RIG-I pathway proteins, and several proteins not previously associated with IFN-3 treatment. the altered proteins might be new therapeutic targets in CHB infection.
